questions.text: A female with chronic dysphagia undergoes an upper endoscopy that reveals massive dilation of the distal esophagus. The esophagus is kinked and tortuous and partly filled with undigested foods. What is the most likely diagnosis for this patient?
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Achalasia

 

Option A:

 

Achalasia: Correct. Achalasia is defined by impaired esophageal motility and relaxation of the lower esophageal sphincter, causing food accumulation and dilation of the esophagus.

 

Explanation:

 

Option B. Barrett’s Esophagus: Incorrect for this scenario. Barrett’s esophagus involves the replacement of the lower esophageal squamous epithelium with columnar epithelium and is associated with chronic GERD, not presenting with significant dilation and kinking as described.

 

Option C. Hiatal Hernia: Incorrect. A hiatal hernia occurs when a portion of the stomach protrudes through the diaphragm into the chest cavity. While it can cause reflux and some degree of dysphagia, it typically doesn't result in the massive dilation and tortuosity of the esophagus.

 

Option D. Plummer-Vinson Syndrome: Incorrect. Plummer-Vinson syndrome is associated with iron-deficiency anemia, glossitis, and esophageal webs. It does not present with the dilation and tortuosity as described in the vignette.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Characteristic presentation of achalasia includes chronic dysphagia, dilation, and tortuosity of the esophagus, often with retained food material, which is distinguishable from other conditions such as Barrett's esophagus, hiatal hernia, and Plummer-Vinson syndrome.

 

Symptoms: Progressive dysphagia to solids and liquids, regurgitation of undigested food, weight loss, sometimes chest pain.

 

Imaging (Barium swallow): “Bird-beak” appearance

 

Ref: Robbins 10th/ 757

questions.text: A 50-year-old male with a clinical presentation of gastric outlet obstruction undergoes endoscopic biopsy of a gastric lesion. Histopathology indicates a mesenchymal tumor consistent with a GIST. Immunohistochemistry is crucial for definitive diagnosis. Which of the following markers is most appropriate for confirming the diagnosis of GIST?
questions.solution:
Ans. D) DOG-1

 

Option D:

 

DOG-1: Discovered on GIST-1 (DOG-1) is a highly sensitive and specific marker for GISTs, used particularly when CD117 may be negative or equivocal.

 

Explanation:

 

Option A. CD34: While CD34 can be expressed in GISTs, it is not as specific as other markers and can be present in a variety of other soft tissue tumors.

 

Option B. CD117: Also known as c-KIT, CD117 is a commonly expressed marker in GISTs and is considered a hallmark of diagnosis. However, it is not exclusive to GISTs and may require additional confirmation.

 

Option C. CD30: This marker is not commonly associated with GISTs and is more typically related to lymphoid malignancies, such as Hodgkin lymphoma and anaplastic large cell lymphoma.

 

Educational Objective:

 

DOG-1 is an important immunohistochemical marker for GISTs, especially when used alongside or in place of CD117, to confirm the diagnosis of GISTs in a biopsy sample.

 

Ref: Robbins 10th/779

questions.text: The following have strong causal association with H. pylori infection except:
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Duodenal adenomas

 

Option D:

 

  • H. pylori infection is not strongly associated with duodenal adenomas, which are benign tumors of the duodenal epithelium.
  • Duodenal adenomas are more commonly associated with familial adenomatous polyposis (FAP) or sporadic mutations rather than H. pylori infection. 

 

Explanation:

 

Option A. Chronic gastritis: There is a strong causal association between H. pylori infection and chronic gastritis. H. pylori is a major cause of chronic active gastritis, characterized by inflammation of the gastric mucosa.

 

Option B. Peptic ulcer disease: H. pylori infection is strongly associated with the development of peptic ulcer disease, particularly duodenal ulcers. H. pylori colonization in the gastric mucosa can lead to mucosal damage and ulcer formation.

 

Option C. Gastric carcinoma: H. pylori infection is considered a major risk factor for the development of gastric carcinoma, particularly intestinal-type gastric adenocarcinoma. Chronic inflammation and mucosal damage induced by H. pylori contribute to the carcinogenic process.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Various gastrointestinal conditions strong causal association with H. pylori infection, including chronic gastritis, peptic ulcer disease, and gastric carcinoma, but Duodenal adenomas do not have a strong causal association with H. pylori infection.

 

Summary:

 

  • H. pylori → chronic gastritis → hyperplastic gastric polyps 
  • H. pylori → gastric adenomas/adenocarcinoma (via atrophic gastritis & intestinal metaplasia) 
  • H. pylori → duodenal ulcers 
  • H. pylori → duodenal adenomas (Not causally related)

 

H. pylori-Associated Infections and Tumors

 

Ref: Robbins 10th/ 774

questions.text: A 63-year-old male with a history of chronic gastritis presents with weight loss and early satiety. An endoscopy with biopsy is performed, revealing a 2 cm lesion in the antrum of the stomach. Histopathology reports a well-differentiated adenocarcinoma. Additional staining shows the cancer is confined to the gastric wall with no evidence of metastasis. In early gastric carcinoma, the malignancy is confined to which of the following layers?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Mucosa and submucosa

 

Option B:

 

Involvement of both the mucosa and submucosa suggests a deeper invasion than option A but still within the confines of the stomach wall, representing an intermediate stage of disease.

 

Explanation:

 

Option A. If a gastric carcinoma is confined to the mucosa, it indicates that the tumor has not penetrated beyond the innermost layer of the stomach, which is associated with a less aggressive disease and often a more favorable prognosis.

 

Option C. Penetration into the muscularis propria denotes a more advanced local invasion compared to options A and B, suggesting a higher risk of further spread and a worse prognosis if not treated promptly.

 

Option D. Invasion of the serosa, the outermost layer of the stomach, implies that the tumor may be at the stage where it is capable of spreading beyond the stomach to adjacent structures or through the peritoneal surface, which would denote a more advanced and aggressive disease.

 

Educational Objective:

 

In early gastric carcinoma, the malignancy confined to the mucosa and submucosa signifies a depth of invasion that is more advanced than the mucosal layer alone, but not yet extending into the muscularis propria or serosa.

 

Ref: Robbins 10th/ 775

choices.text: Decreased growth of luminal bacteria
Decreased likelihood of developing gastric carcino­ma
Decreased plasma concentration of gastrin
Increased production of macrocytic red blood cells

questions.text: A 52-year-old woman presents with a several-month history of epigastric pain, which is relieved by eating. She has a past medical history significant for Hashimoto's thyroiditis. On physical examination, she is found to have mild pallor. Laboratory tests reveal a serum vitamin B12 level of 150 pg/mL (normal: 200-900 pg/mL) and a mean corpuscular volume (MCV) of 110 fL (normal: 80-100 fL). An upper endoscopy shows atrophic gastritis. Which of the following conditions would mostly likely be associated with chronic gastritis (Type A) resulting from autoimmune destruction of parietal cells?
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Increased production of macrocytic red blood cells

 

Option D:

 

Autoimmune destruction of parietal cells impairs the production of intrinsic factor, which is necessary for the absorption of vitamin B12 in the ileum. Vitamin B12 deficiency can result in megaloblastic anemia, characterized by the production of macrocytic (large) red blood cells.

 

Explanation:

 

Option A: Chronic atrophic gastritis, especially when caused by an autoimmune process that destroys parietal cells, leads to hypochlorhydria or achlorhydria. This can result in an increased growth of luminal bacteria, as the acidic environment of the stomach normally serves to limit bacterial overgrowth.

 

Option B: The risk of gastric carcinoma is actually increased in the setting of chronic gastritis, particularly when atrophy is involved. The ongoing inflammation and cellular regeneration can predispose to malignant transformation.

 

Option C: In autoimmune gastritis, the destruction of parietal cells typically leads to a decreased secretion of hydrochloric acid. This would usually result in a compensatory increase in plasma gastrin levels due to loss of negative feedback.

 

Educational Objective:

 

In chronic gastritis type A (autoimmune gastritis), the destruction of parietal cells results in impaired production of intrinsic factor and subsequent vitamin B12 deficiency, leading to megaloblastic anemia with macrocytic red blood cells.

 

 Ref: Robbins 10th/ 769

choices.text: May have a malignant neoplastic transformation
Ileum is the most common site

questions.text: A 45-year-old patient presents with an asymptomatic mass in the upper abdomen found incidentally during a routine health check-up. An endoscopic ultrasound followed by a biopsy confirms the presence of a gastrointestinal stromal tumor (GIST). Which of the following statements regarding GISTs is incorrect?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Ileum is the most common site

 

Option B:

 

The most common site for GISTs is the stomach, not the ileum. This statement is false and contrary to the typical presentation of GISTs.

 

Stomach is the most common site.  These have a tendency for malignant transformation.

 

Explanation:

 

Option A: GISTs have the potential for malignant transformation, which is consistent with their classification as a neoplastic disorder, potentially leading to cancer.

 

Option C: Mutations in the c-KIT gene are commonly associated with GISTs. These mutations are often pathognomonic and a therapeutic target for treatment.

 

Option D: Histologically, GISTs can display spindle-shaped cells, but they can also present with other patterns, such as epithelioid or mixed cell types.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The most common site for GISTs is the stomach.

 

Ref: Robbins 10th/ 779

questions.text: A 60-year-old patient presents with dyspepsia and an upper gastrointestinal endoscopy reveals a lesion in the stomach. Histopathological examination is consistent with gastric carcinoma. Which type of gastric carcinoma is associated with the best prognosis?
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Superficial spreading

 

Option D:

 

Superficial spreading gastric carcinoma, confined to the mucosal layer, is likely to have a more favorable prognosis because of the potential for complete surgical removal and lower likelihood of metastasis.

 

Explanation:

 

Option A: Linitis plastica is known for its poor prognosis because the diffuse infiltration makes it difficult to completely resect and treat effectively.

 

Option B: Polypoidal growths tend to be localized and can often be respected, leading to a relatively better prognosis compared to more invasive forms.

 

Option C: Ulcerative gastric cancers can vary in prognosis. If the ulceration is superficial with minimal invasion, the prognosis can be good, but deeply invasive ulcerations are associated with a poorer outcome.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Superficial spreading gastric carcinoma, which is confined to the mucosal layer and does not invade deeper gastric wall layers, is associated with the best prognosis among the types of gastric carcinoma listed.

 

Why Superficial Spreading Has the Best Prognosis:

 

  • Limited to the mucosa or submucosa (early gastric cancer).
  • Even with wide lateral spread, the depth of invasion is minimal.
  • Often detected early with endoscopic screening (especially in Japan).
  • Excellent 5-year survival rates (>90%) after surgical resection.

 

Ref: Robbins 10th/ 775

questions.text: A 37-year-old woman with a family history of Multiple Endocrine Neoplasia type 1 (MEN I) presents with symptoms of peptic ulcer disease that have not responded to standard treatment. Laboratory tests show elevated serum gastrin levels. Which of the following is the most common functional pancreatic neuroendocrine tumor associated with MEN I in this patient?
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Gastrinoma

 

Option A:

 

Gastrinomas are often the most common functional neuroendocrine tumor in patients with MEN I and are directly related to the symptoms described.

 

Multiple Endocrine Neoplasia type 1 (MEN I) is characterized by tumors involving the parathyroid glands, pancreas, and pituitary gland. Gastrinomas, which are tumors of the pancreas or duodenum that secrete gastrin, are a common functional tumor associated with MEN I. These tumors can lead to Zollinger-Ellison syndrome, characterized by gastric acid hypersecretion and peptic ulcers.

 

Explanation:

 

Option B. Although insulinomas are seen in MEN I, they are not as common as gastrinomas and typically present with symptoms related to hypoglycemia, not peptic ulcer disease.

 

Option C. Lipomas are benign and not typically functional, meaning they do not secrete hormones that lead to the clinical syndromes associated with MEN I.

 

Option D. Glucagonomas are rare neuroendocrine tumors and when present, are associated with a distinct set of clinical features that are not described in this patient.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Gastrinomas are the most common functional pancreatic neuroendocrine tumors associated with MEN I and often present with peptic ulcer disease due to gastric acid hypersecretion.

 

Ref: Robbins 10th /773

choices.text: Infiltration of histiocytes in the lamina propria
Macrophages with PAS (+) material inside the lamina propria

questions.text: A 50-year-old male patient presents with arthralgia, chronic diarrhea, and weight loss. An upper GI endoscopy is performed, and duodenal biopsy samples are obtained. Histological examination of the biopsy will most likely reveal which of the following features consistent with Whipple's disease?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Macrophages with PAS (+) material inside the lamina propria

 

Option C:

 

  • The presence of PAS-positive macrophages in the lamina propria containing small bacilli is a hallmark of Whipple's disease and helps differentiate it from other gastrointestinal diseases.

  • Hallmark of Whipple’s disease had been presence of PAS positive macrophages containing the characteristic small bacilli.  Also know that the presence of T. Whipplei outside of macrophages is more important indicator of active disease than is their presence inside the macrophages.

 

Explanation:

 

Option A. Histiocyte infiltration is a feature seen in many types of chronic inflammation of the GI tract and is not specific to Whipple's disease.

 

Option B. Granulomas are a histological finding seen in diseases like tuberculosis, sarcoidosis and Crohn's disease, but not typically in Whipple's disease.

 

Option D. Eosinophilic infiltration is more commonly seen in conditions associated with allergy, parasitic infection, or certain gastrointestinal disorders but not typically in Whipple's disease.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The histological hallmark of Whipple's disease is the presence of PAS-positive macrophages within the lamina propria, which contain the causative organism Tropheryma whipplei.

 

Ref: Robbins 10th/ 796

questions.text: The biopsy of the small intestine from a patient presenting with gastrointestinal symptoms shows increased cells within the intra-epithelial layer of the mucosa. In the intra-epithelial region of the mucosa of intestine the predominant cell population is that of:
questions.solution:
Ans. B) T-cells

 

Option B:

 

Intra-epithelial lymphocytes (IELs) are predominantly T cells, especially CD8+ T cells in the small intestine, which function in the immune response to pathogens and in maintaining epithelial integrity.

 

Explanation:

 

Option A. B cells are a vital part of the adaptive immune system and are present in the gut-associated lymphoid tissue; however, they are not the predominant cell type in the intra-epithelial region.

 

Option C. Plasma cells are found in the lamina propria where they produce antibodies, especially IgA, which is critical for mucosal immunity, but they are not the primary cell type in the intra-epithelial space.

 

Option D. Basophils are part of the innate immune system and are found in the blood; they are not typically located within the intra-epithelial layer of the intestinal mucosa.

 

Educational Objective:

 

In the intra-epithelial region of the mucosa of the intestine, the predominant cell population is that of CD8+ T-cells, which are dispersed among the luminal epithelial cells.

 

Direct quote. ‘IEL are a distinctive population of T cells dispersed among the luminal epithelial cells. Particular­ly in the small intestine, there is a predominance of CD 8+T cells.

 

 Ref: Mucosal Immunology Elsevier, 3rd/565

choices.text: Increase in thickness of the mucosa
Increase in inflammatory cells in lamina propria

questions.text: A 30-year-old female presents with chronic diarrhea, abdominal pain, and has recently developed a pruritic vesicular rash. Serology tests are positive for anti-tissue transglutaminase antibodies. A biopsy of the small intestine is performed. Which histological finding is least likely to be associated with her probable condition, celiac disease?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Increased in thickness of the mucosa

 

Option B:

 

While there is crypt hyperplasia and increased cell turnover, the mucosal thickness does not increase in celiac disease; instead, there is villous atrophy which makes the mucosa appear flat.

 

Characteristic histological features seen on duode­nal/ jejunal biopsy in celiac sprue are:

 

  • Absence or reduced height of villi, resulting in ‘flat’ appearance.

  • Crypt cell hyperplasia compensate for villous atrophy and mucosal thickness remain same

  • Increased lymphocytes and plasma cells in lamina propria.

 

Explanation:

 

Option A. Crypt hyperplasia is seen in celiac disease and reflects an effort of the mucosa to regenerate despite ongoing damage.

 

Option C. Increased intraepithelial lymphocytes are a diagnostic feature of celiac disease, often exceeding 25 lymphocytes per 100 enterocytes.

 

Option D. In celiac disease, the lamina propria typically shows increased numbers of inflammatory cells, including lymphocytes and plasma cells.

 

Educational Objective:

 

In celiac disease, despite crypt hyperplasia compensating for villous atrophy, the overall thickness of the mucosa does not increase, maintaining a 'flat' appearance.

 

Ref: Robbins 10th/ 785

questions.text: The following cereals should be avoided in patients with celiac diseases, except:
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Maize (Ref: Robbins 10th /785)

 

Explanation:

 

It is a disease characterized by increased sensitivity to a protein called gliadin present in the grains like wheat; oat, barley and rye resulting in a T-cell me­diated chronic inflammatory reaction in the small intestine and impaired absorption. It is associated with HLA-DQ2 or HLA-DQ8.

 

Educational Objective:

 

In celiac disease, the consumption of grains containing gluten should be avoided. Gluten is a protein found in:

 

  1. Wheat

  2. Barley

  3. Rye

 

Ref: Robbins 10th /785

choices.text: Commonest site is ascending colon and cecum

questions.text: A 34-year-old male presents with a two-week history of bloody diarrhea and abdominal pain. Colonoscopy reveals several ulcers in the cecum and ascending colon.  The patient has a travel history to an area with poor sanitation. All are true about amoebic ulcer except:
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Perforation is common

 

Option C:

 

Contrary to this statement, perforation is not a common complication of amoebic ulcers; it is relatively rare and suggests other underlying or superimposed pathologies if present.

 

Explanation:

 

Option A. The cecum and ascending colon are indeed the most common sites for amoebic ulcers, matching the patient's colonoscopic findings.

 

Option B. Flask-shaped ulcers are indicative of amoebic colitis, where the invading Entamoeba histolytica causes deep ulcers with undermined edges.

 

Option D. The histology of amoebic colitis typically shows minimal inflammation, as the trophozoites of Entamoeba histolytica cause cell lysis and necrosis without inducing a significant inflammatory response.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Amoebic ulcers are typically seen in the colon, particularly in the cecum and ascending colon. They are associated with amoebic colitis caused by the protozoan parasite Entamoeba histolytica. These ulcers are usually deep with undermined edges, giving them the flask-shaped appearance. Perforation is not a common feature of amoebic ulcers

 

 

Ref: Robbins 10th/ 796

questions.text: All are complication of typhoid ulcers except:
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Stricture formation

 

Option B:

 

Stricture formation is not usually seen with enteric fever. It is a feature with intestinal tuberculosis.

 

Explanation:

 

Option A. Perforation: Perforation is a well-known complication of typhoid ulcers. The ulcers can penetrate through the intestinal wall, leading to perforation and potentially causing peritonitis.

 

Option C. Hemorrhage: Typhoid ulcers can cause bleeding, and hemorrhage is a recognized complication. Ulceration and erosion of blood vessels within the intestinal wall can result in gastrointestinal bleeding.

 

Option D. Sepsis: Perforation of typhoid ulcers can allow the entry of bacteria into the abdominal cavity, leading to sepsis. Sepsis is a severe, life-threatening complication that can result from the spread of bacteria and their toxins.

 

Ref: Robbins 10th/ 791

questions.text: A 40-year-old male presents with a history of bloody diarrhea and abdominal pain. A colonoscopy reveals ulcerations. Biopsies are taken, and the patient is diagnosed with amoebic colitis caused by Entamoeba histolytica. The most common site for amoebiasis:
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Cecum

 

Option C:

 

Amoebic ulcers are typically seen in the colon, particularly in the cecum and ascending colon. They are associated with amoebic colitis caused by the protozoan parasite Entamoeba histolytica. These ulcers are usually deep with undermined edges, giving them the flask-shaped appearance.

 

The cecum, followed by the ascending colon, is the most frequent location for amoebic ulcers within the colon due to factors such as stasis and bacterial content, providing a conducive environment for Entamoeba histolytica.

 

Explanation:

 

Option A. The sigmoid colon can be affected by amoebic colitis, but it is not the most common site of amoebic involvement in the colon.

 

Option B. Amoebiasis may involve the transverse colon, but such involvement is less common than in the cecum and ascending colon.

 

Option D. The liver is indeed the most common extraintestinal site affected by amoebiasis, often resulting from hematogenous spread from the intestinal lesion, but within the intestine itself, the cecum is the most commonly affected site.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The cecum is the most common site for amoebiasis within the intestine, presenting typically with deep ulcers that have undermined edges, often giving a flask-shaped appearance.

 

Ref: Robbins 10th /795

choices.text: Remnant of proximal part of vitellointestinal duct
Present in 3% of the population

questions.text: What is false about Meckel’s diverticulitis?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Present in 3% of the population

 

Option C:

 

Meckel diverticulum occurs as a result of failed involu­tion of the vitelline duct, which connects the lumen of the developing gut to the yolk sac. This solitary divertic­ulum extends from the antimesenteric side of the bowel.

 

The “rule of 2s” is often used to help remember charac­teristics of Meckel diverticula, which:

 

The prevalence of Meckel's diverticulum in the general population is 2%, not 3%, making this statement false.

 

  • Affects 2% of the population

  • Are generally present within 2 feet (60 cm) of the ileocecal valve

  • Are approximately 2 inches (5 cm) long

  • Are twice as common in males

  • Are most often symptomatic by age 2 (only approximately 4% are ever symptomatic).

  • Has 2 types of mucosa: gastric and pancreatic mucosa.

 

Explanation:

 

Option A. The proximal part of the vitellointestinal duct is the correct embryological origin of Meckel's diverticulum.

 

Option B. Symptoms of Meckel's diverticulitis may include periumbilical pain, which sometimes leads to a clinical picture resembling that of acute appendicitis.

 

Option D. Meckel's diverticulum is indeed located on the anti-mesenteric border of the ileum, which is the edge of the intestine that is not attached to the mesentery.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Meckel's diverticulum is present in 2% of the population, not 3%.

 

Ref: Robbins 10th/ 755

questions.text: In Peutz-Jeghers syndrome, polyps are mainly seen in:
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Jejunum

 

Option D:

 

The polyps of Peutz-Jeghers syndrome (PJS) are most com­mon in the small intestine especially jejunum, although they may occur in the stomach and colon, and, with much lower frequency, in the bladder and lungs.

 

The jejunum is the most frequently affected site, and patients with Peutz-Jeghers syndrome often develop polyps here that can cause complications like intussusception.

 

Explanation:

 

Option A. Rectal involvement is possible in Peutz-Jeghers syndrome, but it is not the primary site of polyp development.

 

Option B. The colon can be involved, but the small intestine, particularly the jejunum, is the most common site for polyps in this syndrome.

 

Option C. Esophageal polyps are quite uncommon in Peutz-Jeghers syndrome, with the condition typically affecting the small intestine.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Jejunum is the most common site for the characteristic hamartomatous polyps of Peutz-Jeghers syndrome.

 

Location of Polyps in PJS:

 

 

Ref: Robbins 10th/ 809

choices.text: Polyps develop in early adulthood
Epidermal cysts and osteomas may occur

questions.text: In the clinical evaluation of a patient with a strong family history of colorectal cancer, which of the following characteristics is not consistent with familial adenomatous polyposis (FAP)?
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Autosomal recessive inheritance

 

Option A:

 

FAP is an autosomal dominant condition

 

  • Familial polyposis syndrome (FAP) is an autosomal domi­nant disorder.

  • It is caused by mutation in the adeno­matous polyposis coli or APC gene on chromosome 5q21.

  • At least 100 polyps are necessary for a diagnosis of FAP.

  • Since colorectal carci­noma develop in 100% of untreated FAP patients often before age 30, so, prophylactic colectomy is the standard therapy in patients with APC mutations.

 

Explanation:

 

Option B. Screening for polyps in individuals with FAP or at risk of FAP is typically performed with sigmoidoscopy or colonoscopy, as polyps tend to occur throughout the colon.

 

Option C. Polyp development in FAP usually starts in the teenage years or early adulthood and if left untreated, these polyps can lead to colorectal cancer, often before the age of 30.

 

Option D. Associated features of FAP may include various extracolonic manifestations, including epidermal cysts, osteomas, and other benign growths, which are true.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Familial adenomatous polyposis (FAP) is an autosomal dominant disorder, not an autosomal recessive condition.

 

Ref: Robbins 10th/ 812

questions.text: A 25-year-old patient with a history of chronic bloody diarrhea undergoes a colonoscopy. The procedure reveals continuous colonic mucosal inflammation extending proximally from the rectum to the cecum, and notable inflammation of the terminal ileum. Backwash ileitis is seen in:
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Ulcerative colitis

 

Option B:

 

Ulcerative colitis commonly presents with continuous colonic inflammation that may extend proximally in a continuous fashion from the rectum. When it involves the terminal ileum, this is referred to as backwash ileitis.

 

Explanation:

 

Option A. Crohn's disease is characterized by patchy, "skip" areas of inflammation, which can involve any part of the GI tract from the mouth to the anus. While ileal involvement is common in Crohn's, the continuous inflammation pattern described does not typically occur.

 

Option C. Colonic carcinoma may lead to secondary inflammation due to obstruction or invasion but does not cause backwash ileitis.

 

Option D. Ileal polyps may be a feature of various polyposis syndromes but are not associated with backwash ileitis, which is specifically related to inflammatory bowel disease.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Backwash ileitis refers to the extension of inflammatory changes from the colon into the terminal ileum and is associated with ulcerative colitis, not Crohn's disease, colonic carcinoma, or ileal polyps.

 

Ref: Robbins 10th/ 801

questions.text: A 17-year-old presented with intussusception and was found to be having a polyp. A biopsy is taken and is shown alongside. What is the likely diagnosis in this individual?
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Peutz Jegher polyp

 

Option D:

 

The Peutz-Jegher polyp is part of an autosomal dominant syndrome characterized by hamartomatous polyps throughout the gastrointestinal tract. The biopsy showing an arborizing pattern aligns with the diagnosis of Peutz-Jeghers syndrome, fitting with the patient's clinical presentation

 

Explanation:

 

Option A. Juvenile polyps do not typically cause intussusception in older children or teenagers and are not characterized by an arborizing architecture on histology.

 

Option B. Adenomatous polyps are neoplastic and could be associated with intussusception; however, they do not show the arborizing histological pattern seen in the provided biopsy.

 

Option C. Tubulovillous adenomas are not typically associated with the genetic syndrome in question and do not have the arborizing architecture shown in the biopsy.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The histological pattern of the polyp and the clinical presentation of intussusception at a young age suggest a diagnosis of Peutz-Jeghers syndrome. This condition is associated with hamartomatous polyps that have a tree-like architectural pattern and increased cancer risk.

 

Ref: Robbins 10th 809-810

choices.text: Majority of patients have associated atopic conditions
Feline esophagus is an endoscopic finding
Treatment of choice is high dose proton pump inhibitors
May be associated with food products like cow's milk and soy products

questions.text: Which of the following is incorrect about Eosinophilic esophagitis (EoE)?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Treatment of choice is high dose proton pump inhibitors

 

Option C:

 

The mainstay of treatment for EoE involves dietary modifications to eliminate food allergens and the use of topical steroids to reduce eosinophilic inflammation, not high-dose PPIs.

 

Explanation:

 

Option A. Patients with EoE frequently have concurrent atopic conditions, which is a helpful clue in the diagnosis of this condition.

 

Option B. Feline esophagus is a term used to describe the ringed appearance of the esophagus seen during endoscopy in patients with EoE.

 

Option D. Food allergens such as cow's milk and soy are often implicated in EoE, and dietary elimination of these can be part of the management.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The incorrect statement is (c). The treatment of choice for eosinophilic esophagitis is not high-dose proton pump inhibitors but rather dietary modifications and steroids.

 

Ref: Robbins 10th/ 760

questions.text: A 12-year-old male presented with bloating of abdomen and steatorrhea. His HLA DQ2 was positive. Which of the following is the diet modification helping in the improvement of the condition of the patient?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Low gluten diet

 

Option C:

 

Celiac disease is treated by removing gluten from the diet, which is found in wheat, barley, rye, and their derivatives. This prevents the immune response that damages the small intestine.

 

Explanation:

 

Option A. A low-fat diet can be recommended for specific conditions such as pancreatitis or gallbladder disease, but celiac disease primarily requires the elimination of gluten from the diet.

 

Option B. While a balanced diet is important, the focus for treating celiac disease is on removing gluten, which is the trigger for the autoimmune response causing the symptoms.

 

Option D. Reducing calorie intake does not have a role in the management of celiac disease unless there are concurrent issues with obesity or metabolic syndrome.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The most effective dietary modification for a patient with celiac disease, suggested by the symptoms of malabsorption and a positive HLA DQ2, is a gluten-free diet.

 

Ref: Robbins 10th /e p784

choices.text: Multinucleate giant cells in the bronchiolar wall

questions.text: All of the following features are seen in the viral pneumonia except:
questions.solution:
Ans. B. Predominance of alveolar exudate

 

Option B:

 

Predominance of alveolar exudate: Alveolar exudate is characteristic of bacterial pneumonia, where the alveoli are filled with fluid and inflammatory cells. This feature is less common in viral pneumonia, which tends to involve the interstitium and bronchioles more than the alveoli.

 

Explanation:

 

Option A. Presence of interstitial inflammation: This is a common feature in viral pneumonia, where the infection leads to inflammation predominantly in the tissue and space around the air sacs of the lungs.

 

Option C. Bronchiolitis: Bronchiolitis, which is inflammation of the small airways or bronchioles, is commonly seen in viral pneumonia.

 

Option D. Multinucleate giant cells in the bronchiolar wall: The presence of multinucleate giant cells is a histopathological feature sometimes seen in viral infections, reflecting the body's response to viral replication within cells.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The predominance of alveolar exudate is not a feature commonly seen in viral pneumonia; instead, it is a hallmark of bacterial pneumonia. Viral pneumonia typically presents with interstitial inflammation, bronchiolitis, and can have multinucleate giant cells in the bronchiolar wall.

 

Histopathological Features of Viral Pneumonia:

 

 

(Ref: Robbins 10th/ 708)

questions.text: A medical resident is reviewing the pathology of tuberculosis (TB) with their attending. They are trying to differentiate the features of primary TB from secondary (reactivation) TB. Which of the following is least likely to be found in primary tuberculosis?
questions.solution:
Ans. A. Cavitation

 

Option A:

 

Cavitation: Cavitation is more characteristic of secondary TB, occurring when previously sensitized host defenses mobilize to contain a reactivated infection, resulting in caseous necrosis and cavity formation in the lungs.

 

Explanation:

 

Option B: Caseation: Caseation, which is a form of necrosis associated with TB, can occur in both primary and secondary tuberculosis as part of the granuloma formation process.

 

Option C: Calcification: Calcification in primary TB is part of the Ghon complex, representing healing and containment of the infection, often seen in primary TB lesions.

 

Option D: Langhans giant cell: Langhans giant cells are a type of multinucleated giant cell seen in granulomas and can be found in both primary and secondary TB as part of the body's immune response to the infection.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Cavitation is more frequently associated with secondary tuberculosis, where a previously sensitized host's immune response leads to caseous necrosis and cavity formation. This feature is less commonly observed in primary tuberculosis.

 

(Ref: Robbins 10th/ 375)

questions.text: A 45-year-old man presents to the emergency department with a three-day history of productive cough, fever, and pleuritic chest pain. Chest X-ray reveals lobar consolidation in the right lower lobe. On histopathological examination, the affected lung tissue shows grey hepatisation. Which of the following is a finding of this patient?
questions.solution:
Ans. D. Accumulation of fibrin

 

Option D:

 

Accumulation of fibrin: During the grey hepatisation stage of pneumonia, there is a persistent fibrinopurulent exudate with the breakdown of red blood cells, leading to a greyish appearance of lung tissue due to an ongoing inflammatory response.

 

Explanation:

 

Option A: WBCs fill the alveoli: While white blood cells are present in the alveoli during pneumonia, the term "grey hepatisation" does not specifically refer to this feature.

 

Option B: RBCs fill the alveoli: Red blood cells contribute to the earlier stage known as red hepatisation, not the grey hepatisation stage of pneumonia.

 

Option C: Organisms fill the alveoli: While infectious organisms cause the pneumonia, the term "grey hepatisation" refers to the stage characterized by the breakdown of red blood cells and inflammatory cells, rather than the presence of organisms.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Grey hepatisation in pneumonia is characterized by the accumulation of fibrin and breakdown of red blood cells, with a predominance of leukocytes, corresponding with a more advanced stage of lung tissue consolidation.

 

Stages of Lobar Pneumonia:

 

 

(Ref: Robbins 10th/ 706)

questions.text: Gray hepatization of lungs is seen on which days:
questions.solution:
Ans. D. 5-7

 

Option D:

 

In the stages of bacterial pneumonia:

 

  1. Congestion (Day 1-2): The affected lobe becomes heavy and hyperemic due to increased blood flow. The alveoli are filled with organisms, fibrin, and bacteria.
  2. Red Hepatization (Day 2-4): The lung appears red and firm due to continued congestion. There is an influx of red blood cells (RBCs) and fibrin into the alveoli, leading to a solid, liver-like consistency.
  3. Gray Hepatization (Day 4-7): The red color fades, and the lung becomes gray-brown. This stage is characterized by ongoing inflammation, presence of fibrinopurulent exudate, and persistence of inflammatory cells.
  4. Resolution (beyond day 7): The inflammation gradually subsides, and macrophages clear the debris from the alveoli. The lung returns to normal architecture.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Gray hepatization of lungs is seen on day 5-7 of bacterial pneumonia.

 

(Ref: Harsh Mohan 6/e p469)

questions.text: A 45-year-old patient, previously treated for pulmonary tuberculosis, presents with cough, hemoptysis, and weight loss. He has been diagnosed with reactivation of tuberculosis. This lesion is most likely to be located near:
questions.solution:
Ans. A. Apex

 

Option A:

 

 Reactivated tuberculosis (TB) typically occurs in areas of the lung where the oxygen tension is higher. Let's analyze each option:

 

Apex: This is a common site for reactivated TB. The apex of the lung has a relatively higher oxygen perfusion ratio.

 

Explanation:

 

Option B. Near bronchus: TB can occur near bronchi, but reactivation often happens in areas with higher oxygen tension.

 

Option C. Subpleurally: TB can occur subpleurally, but reactivation is more common in areas with higher oxygen tension.

 

Option D. Base: The base of the lung has lower oxygen perfusion ratio, making it less favorable for reactivated TB.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Reactivated tuberculosis (TB) typically occurs in apex of lung.

 

(Ref: Robbins 10th 370)

questions.text: A 35-year-old woman presents with a persistent cough, night sweats, and unintentional weight loss. Chest X-ray reveals an infiltrate in the upper lobe of the right lung. Which of the following is the earliest feature of tuberculosis?
questions.solution:
Ans. B. Recruitment of lymphocytes

 

Option B:

 

Recruitment of lymphocytes: The initial immune response to M. tuberculosis includes recruitment of lymphocytes to the site of infection. This is part of the early host defense, which precedes granuloma formation.

 

Explanation:

 

Option A: Caseation: Caseation, a form of necrosis typical of tuberculosis, is a later feature that occurs after the immune system has attempted to contain the infection.

 

Option C: Formation of giant cells (Langhans): Giant cell formation is part of the granuloma response and occurs after lymphocyte recruitment, as part of the body's attempt to wall off and contain the infection.

 

Option D: Granuloma formation: Granuloma formation is a hallmark of the body's defense against tuberculosis but is not the earliest event. It occurs after lymphocytes and macrophages have been recruited to the site of infection.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Recruitment of lymphocytes is the earliest feature in the immune response to M. tuberculosis infection. Following infection, lymphocytes are recruited, leading to the activation of macrophages and subsequent granuloma formation.

 

(Ref: Robbins 10th/ 378)

questions.text: A 45-year-old patient presents with a chronic cough and dyspnea. The sputum analysis reveals the presence of Charcot-Leyden crystals and Curschmann's spirals. Which of the following respiratory conditions is most likely associated with these findings?
questions.solution:
Ans. A. Bronchial asthma

 

Option A:

 

Bronchial asthma have the sputum findings like Charcot-Leyden crystals (needle-shaped crystals composed of eosinophilic membrane protein) and Curschmann's spirals (spiral-shaped mucus plugs formed by the shedding of the bronchial mucosa).

 

Explanation:

 

Option B: Chronic bronchitis is characterized by inflammation of the bronchi, leading to increased mucus production and a persistent cough.

 

Option C: Bronchiectasis: In bronchiectasis, there is irreversible dilation of the bronchi.

 

Option D: Emphysema is characterized by the destruction of alveolar walls and airspace enlargement.

 

However, Charcot-Leyden crystals and Curschmann's spirals are not typically associated with chronic bronchitis, bronchiectasis and emphysema.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The presence of Charcot-Leyden crystals and Curschmann's spirals in sputum is characteristic of bronchial asthma, reflecting eosinophilic inflammation and shedding of the bronchial mucosa, respectively, and are not typically found in chronic bronchitis, bronchiectasis, or emphysema.

 

(Ref: Robbins 10th/ 685)

questions.text: A 60-year-old patient with a history of smoking presents with progressive dyspnea and a chronic cough. Pulmonary function tests impaired expiratory flow. Chest imaging shows reveal hyperinflation. Which type of emphysema is most commonly associated with this clinical presentation?
questions.solution:
Ans. B. Centriacinar

 

Option B:

 

Centriacinar emphysema predominantly affects the central or proximal part of the acinus, sparing the peripheral parts. It is commonly associated with cigarette smoking. It has the maximum prevalence clinically.

 

Explanation:

 

Option A. Panacinar Emphysema: Panacinar emphysema involves the destruction of the entire respiratory acinus, including the respiratory bronchiole, alveolar ducts, and alveoli. It is often associated with alpha-1 antitrypsin deficiency.

 

Option C. Paraseptal Emphysema: Paraseptal emphysema, also known as distal acinar emphysema, involves the distal parts of the acinus, particularly the alveolar ducts and alveoli near the pleura. It often occurs adjacent to scars or fibrotic tissue, and it is associated with spontaneous pneumothorax.

 

Option D. Segmental Emphysema: Segmental emphysema refers to localized areas of emphysematous changes within a lung segment. It can occur in association with scarring or inflammation. While it is less common than other types of emphysema, it may contribute to localized airflow obstruction.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Centriacinar emphysema, is most commonly associated with cigarette smoking and predominantly affects the central parts of the acinus, leading to symptoms like progressive dyspnea and chronic cough in smokers.

 

(Ref: Robbins 10th/ 678)

questions.text: Ferruginous bodies are seen in:
questions.solution:
Ans. C. Asbestosis

 

 

Option C:

 

Asbestosis: Asbestosis is a lung disease caused by the inhalation of asbestos fibers. Ferruginous bodies are specifically associated with asbestos exposure. These bodies are formed when iron-containing proteins coat asbestos fibers in the lungs.

 

Explanation:

 

Option A: Silicosis: Silicosis is a lung disease caused by the inhalation of crystalline silica dust.

 

Option B: Byssinosis: Byssinosis, also known as "brown lung disease" or "Monday fever," is an occupational lung disease caused by the inhalation of cotton, flax, or hemp dust.

 

Option D: Bagassosis: Bagassosis is a type of pneumoconiosis caused by the inhalation of dust from moldy sugarcane.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Ferruginous bodies are not typically associated with silicosis, byssinosis and bagassosis.

 

(Ref: Robbins 10th/ 701)

questions.text: All of the following are seen in asbestosis except:
questions.solution:
Ans. A. Diffuse alveolar damage

 

Option A:

 

Diffuse alveolar damage: is not a typical finding in asbestosis. Asbestosis is characterized by diffuse pulmonary interstitial fibrosis rather than diffuse alveolar damage. Diffuse alveolar damage is more commonly associated with conditions such as acute respiratory distress syndrome (ARDS).

 

Explanation:

 

Option B: Calcified pleural plaques: This is a characteristic feature of asbestosis. Asbestos exposure can lead to the formation of pleural plaques, which are areas of fibrous thickening and calcification on the pleura. These plaques are a hallmark of asbestos-related lung disease.

 

Option C: Diffuse pulmonary interstitial fibrosis: This is a correct option. Asbestosis is primarily characterized by the deposition of asbestos fibers in the lungs, leading to pulmonary fibrosis. It involves the interstitium of the lungs, causing scarring and impairment of lung function.

 

Option D: Mesothelioma: This is a correct option. Asbestos exposure is a well-established risk factor for the development of mesothelioma, a malignant tumor of the mesothelial cells lining the pleura, peritoneum, and other serosal surfaces.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Diffuse alveolar damage is not typically associated with asbestosis but is more indicative of acute conditions such as acute respiratory distress syndrome (ARDS), distinguishing it from the chronic fibrotic changes seen in asbestosis.

 

(Ref: Robbins 10th/ 672)

questions.text: Hyaline membrane disease is associated with:
questions.solution:
Ans. A. Respiratory distress syndrome

 

Option A:

 

Respiratory Distress Syndrome, also known as hyaline membrane disease, primarily affects premature infants. It occurs due to a deficiency of surfactant in the lungs, leading to difficulty in maintaining lung expansion and causing respiratory distress. The hyaline membranes, composed of proteins and cellular debris, form in the alveoli, hindering normal gas exchange.

 

Explanation:

 

Option B: Bronchopulmonary Dysplasia (BPD): Bronchopulmonary dysplasia is a chronic lung disease that can affect premature infants who have received mechanical ventilation and oxygen therapy for respiratory distress. It is characterized by inflammation and scarring in the lungs, leading to long-term respiratory problems.

 

Option C: Sudden Infant Death Syndrome (SIDS): Sudden Infant Death Syndrome is the sudden, unexplained death of an otherwise healthy infant, usually during sleep. It is not directly associated with hyaline membrane disease or the other respiratory conditions mentioned.

 

Option D: Bronchiolitis Obliterans: Bronchiolitis obliterans is a condition involving inflammation and scarring of the small airways (bronchioles) in the lungs. It can be associated with various causes, including infections and exposures to certain substances, but it is not specifically associated with hyaline membrane disease.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Respiratory Distress Syndrome, also termed hyaline membrane disease, is primarily caused by surfactant deficiency in premature infants, leading to the formation of hyaline membranes in the alveoli and subsequent respiratory distress.

 

(Ref: Robbins 10th/ 460)

questions.text: Which condition is Caplan’s syndrome associated with?
questions.solution:
Ans. B. Pneumoconiosis

 

Option B:

 

Pneumoconiosis refers to a group of lung diseases caused by the inhalation of certain dusts and includes diseases like silicosis, asbestosis, and coal worker's pneumoconiosis. Caplan’s syndrome is an association of rheumatoid arthritis with pneumoconiosis, particularly seen in coal miners.

 

Explanation:

 

Option A: COPD, or Chronic Obstructive Pulmonary Disease, is a common respiratory condition, primarily due to smoking, that causes obstructed airflow from the lungs and includes emphysema and chronic bronchitis. It is not associated with Caplan's syndrome.

 

Option C: Pulmonary edema is a condition characterized by excess fluid in the lungs and is usually related to heart conditions or acute injury, not associated with Caplan’s syndrome.

 

Option D: Bronchial asthma is a chronic inflammatory disease of the airways characterized by variable and recurring symptoms, reversible airflow obstruction, and bronchospasm. Asthma is not linked to Caplan’s syndrome.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Pneumoconiosis is the condition associated with Caplan's syndrome, which is the coexistence of rheumatoid arthritis and a pneumoconiosis, often coal worker's pneumoconiosis.

 

Key Features:

 

  • Seen in coal miners or silica-exposed workers with Rheumatoid Arthritis
  • Radiologically: Multiple, well-defined, round nodules in both lungs
  • Histologically: Nodules show central necrosis surrounded by macrophages and fibrosis
  • Associated with positive rheumatoid factor (RF)

 

(Ref: Robbins 10th /688)

questions.text: In a specimen of kidney, fibrinoid necrosis is seen and onion peel appearance is also present. Most probable pathology is:
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Hyperplastic arteriosclerosis

 

Option B:

 

 

Explanation:

 

Option A: Hyaline degeneration refers to the accumulation of homogenous, eosinophilic material (hyaline) in tissues. It is not typically associated with fibrinoid necrosis or an onion peel appearance.

 

Option C: Glomerulosclerosis involves scarring and hardening of the glomeruli in the kidneys. It may not typically present with fibrinoid necrosis and an onion peel appearance.

 

Option D: Fibrillary glomerulonephritis is a renal disease characterized by the deposition of fibrillary immune complexes in the glomeruli. Fibrinoid necrosis and an onion peel appearance are not typically associated with fibrillary glomerulonephritis.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Hyperplastic arteriosclerosis is characterized by "onion skin" or "string of beads" appearance.

 

(Ref: Robbins 10th/ 935)

questions.text: A person with radiologically confirmed reflux nephropathy develops nephrotic range proteinuria. Which of the following would be the most likely histological finding in this patient?
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Focal segmental glomerulosclerosis

 

Option A:

 

Reflux nephropathy is characterized by chronic inflammation and scarring due to vesicoureteral reflux. Nephrotic range proteinuria suggests glomerular involvement, and focal segmental glomerulosclerosis is a common cause of nephrotic syndrome.

 

Direct quote…‘FSGS occurs as a component of the adaptive response to loss of renal tissue in advanced stage of other renal disorders such as reflux nephropathy, hypertensive nephropathy and  unilateral renal agenesis.’

 

Explanation:

 

Option C: Membranous glomerulopathy is characterized by the thickening of the glomerular basement membrane, often forming immune complexes.

 

Option B: Nodular glomerulosclerosis is not a common feature of reflux nephropathy. It is seen with diabetic nephropathy.

 

Option D: Proliferative glomerulonephritis with crescents is more associated with nephritic range proteinuria rather than nephrotic range.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Reflux nephropathy and nephrotic range proteinuria are commonly seen in Focal segmental glomerulosclerosis.

 

(Ref Robbins 10th/ 915)

choices.text: Her C3 levels will be low
No IgG deposits or C3 deposition on renal biopsy

questions.text: A 7 yrs old girl is brought with complaints of generalized swelling of the body. Urinary examination reveals grade 3 proteinuria and the presence of hyaline and fatty casts. She has no history of hematuria. Which of the following statements about her condition is true?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) No IgG deposits or C3 deposition on renal biopsy

 

Option C:

 

In minimal change disease (MCD), the most common cause of nephrotic syndrome in children, renal biopsies do not show IgG deposits or C3 deposition. MCD is characterized by the effacement of podocyte foot processes and is often responsive to corticosteroids.

 

The clinical symptoms and the findings in the stem of the question (child with generalized swelling because of reduced serum protein secondary to massive proteinuria with urinary lipid casts) are suggestive of nephrotic syndrome. The commonest cause in a child of nephrotic syndrome is lipoid nephrosis or minimal change disease.

 

Explanation:

 

Option A: IgA nephropathy is a common cause of glomerulonephritis that often presents with hematuria following an upper respiratory tract infection, making it less likely in this case without a history of hematuria.

 

Option B: Low C3 levels are typically associated with complement-mediated conditions such as post-infectious glomerulonephritis or membranoproliferative glomerulonephritis, not typically seen in minimal change disease.

 

Option D: Alport syndrome is characterized by hematuria, progressive renal failure, and hearing loss, and is caused by genetic mutations affecting type IV collagen; it is not the most likely diagnosis given the absence of hematuria and the patient's presentation.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The most likely diagnosis for a child presenting with nephrotic syndrome and no hematuria, evidenced by proteinuria and lipiduria, is minimal change disease. This condition does not show IgG deposits or C3 deposition on renal biopsy, and electron microscopy would reveal effacement of the podocyte foot processes.

 

(Ref: Robbin’s 10th/ 914)

questions.text: Pathological changes of diabetic nephropathy are all except:
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Focal glomerular sclerosis

 

Option D:

 

Diabetic nephropathy is characterized by several pathological changes, and the options provided are associated with these changes:

 

Explanation:

 

Option A. Fibrin caps and capsular drops: These are characteristic of diabetic nephropathy. Fibrin caps are formed from the extravasation of plasma proteins into Bowman's space, and capsular drops are hyaline droplets in the renal tubules.

 

Option B. Kimmelstein-Wilson lesion: This refers to nodular glomerulosclerosis, which is a classic finding in diabetic nephropathy.

 

Option C. Basement membrane thickening: Thickening of the glomerular basement membrane is a hallmark of diabetic nephropathy.

 

Focal glomerular sclerosis (FSGS) is not a typical finding in diabetic nephropathy. It is a separate entity that can be associated with other conditions.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The characteristic pathological features of diabetic nephropathy, include Kimmelstiel-Wilson lesions (nodular glomerulosclerosis), thickening of the glomerular basement membrane, and the presence of fibrin caps and capsular drops.

 

(Ref: Robbins 10th/ 923)

questions.text: What is the cause of hypercoagulation in nephrotic syndrome?
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Loss of antithrombin III (AT III)

 

Option A:

 

Loss of antithrombin III (AT III): In nephrotic syndrome, there is increased urinary loss of proteins including antithrombin III, which is a natural anticoagulant. AT III inhibits thrombin and factor Xa in the coagulation cascade. Its loss contributes significantly to the hypercoagulable state in nephrotic syndrome.

 

Thrombotic and thromboembolic complications are com­mon in nephrotic syndrome due to loss of anticoagulant factor (e.g. antithrombin III, protein C and S) combined with increased platelet activation. Renal vein thrombo­sis is most often a consequence of this hypercoagulative state. There is also increased synthesis of fibrinogen in the liver.

 

The hypercoagulable state in nephrotic syndrome is multifactorial.

 

Explanation:

 

Option B: Decreased fibrinogen: This statement is incorrect with respect to nephrotic syndrome. Actually, there is an increased synthesis of fibrinogen in the liver, not decreased. Fibrinogen is an acute phase reactant, and its levels are increased in nephrotic syndrome, which contributes to a hypercoagulable state.

 

Option C: Decreased metabolism of vitamin K: This statement is not directly related to the hypercoagulable state in nephrotic syndrome. Vitamin K is essential for the synthesis of certain clotting factors (II, VII, IX, X), and its metabolism can be affected in liver disease, not typically in nephrotic syndrome.

 

Option D: Increase in Protein C: This is not correct. While Protein C is an anticoagulant, similar to antithrombin III, in nephrotic syndrome, there can be a loss of Protein C through the urine, which would contribute to a hypercoagulable state rather than mitigating it.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Nephrotic syndrome is associated with a hypercoagulable state primarily due to urinary losses of anticoagulant proteins such as antithrombin III, often leading to thrombotic complications like renal vein thrombosis. The liver's increased synthesis of procoagulant factors such as fibrinogen also contributes to this state.

 

(Ref: Robbins 10h/ 911)

questions.text: A 45-year-old man with a history of autoimmune disorders presents with fatigue, edema, and cola-colored urine. Laboratory studies reveal elevated serum creatinine, proteinuria, and hematuria. Urinalysis shows dysmorphic red blood cells and red cell casts. Renal biopsy reveals cellular crescents and fibrinoid necrosis in glomeruli. Which of these does not cause crescentic glomerulone­phritis?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Alport syndrome

 

Option B:

 

Alport syndrome is a genetic disorder caused by mutations in genes encoding type IV collagen. It primarily affects the kidneys, ears, and eyes. However, crescentic glomerulonephritis is not a characteristic feature of Alport syndrome.

 

Crescentic glomerulonephritis is a histopathological pattern of glomerular injury characterized by the presence of crescents in Bowman's space. Various diseases and conditions can cause crescentic glomerulonephritis. Let's look at the provided options:

 

Explanation:

 

Option A: Rapidly progressive glomerulonephritis (RPGN) is a term used to describe a clinical presentation rather than a specific disease. Conditions like ANCA-associated vasculitis, anti-GBM (Goodpasture's syndrome), and immune complex-mediated glomerulonephritis can present as RPGN with crescents.

 

Option C: Goodpasture's syndrome is an autoimmune disease characterized by the presence of anti-GBM antibodies. It can lead to rapidly progressive glomerulonephritis with crescent formation.

 

Option D: Henoch-Schönlein purpura (HSP) is a systemic vasculitis that affects small vessels, including glomerular capillaries. Crescentic glomerulonephritis can occur in some cases of HSP.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Alport syndrome does not cause crescentic glomerulone­phritis.

 

(Ref: Robbins 10th/ p922)

questions.text: Kidney biopsy from a child with hemolytic uremic syndrome characteristically most likely presents features of:
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Thrombotic microangiopathy

 

Option A:

 

Thrombotic Microangiopathy: This is the correct diagnosis for hemolytic uremic syndrome (HUS). It involves the presence of microthrombi in the small blood vessels of the kidney, which leads to mechanical damage to red blood cells as they pass through the partially occluded vessels, causing a characteristic type of anemia known as microangiopathic hemolytic anemia, along with thrombocytopenia due to platelet consumption and acute kidney injury.

 

Explanation:

 

Option B: Proliferative Glomerulonephritis: This involves an increase in the number of cells in the glomeruli, typically due to an immune or inflammatory response. It is not typically associated with HUS, which is characterized by microangiopathic changes rather than cellular proliferation in the glomeruli.

 

Option C: Focal Segmental Glomerulosclerosis (FSGS): This condition is characterized by segments of the glomeruli showing scarring, which can lead to proteinuria and nephrotic syndrome. While FSGS can result in renal failure, it is not a characteristic feature of HUS.

 

Option D: Minimal Change Disease: This is a kidney disorder that causes nephrotic syndrome, especially in children, and is characterized by minimal changes detectable by light microscopy. It's associated with good prognosis and typically responds well to steroids.

 

Educational Objective:

 

In patients presenting with the clinical triad of microangiopathic hemolytic anemia, thrombocytopenia, and acute kidney injury, a kidney biopsy is likely to reveal thrombotic microangiopathy, a pathology characteristic of hemolytic uremic syndrome.

 

(Ref: Robbins 10th/ 939)

questions.text: Serum C3 is persistently low in the following except:
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Post streptococcal glomerulonephritis

 

Option A:

 

Post Streptococcal Glomerulonephritis: After an infection with certain strains of Streptococcus, serum C3 levels typically decrease due to activation of the complement system. However, this decrease is transient and serum C3 levels usually normalize within 6 to 8 weeks. Therefore, persistently low serum C3 levels are not characteristic of poststreptococcal glomerulonephritis.

 

Explanation:

 

The terms of serum C3 levels in different renal pathologies:

 

Option B: Membranoproliferative Glomerulonephritis type II: This condition can cause persistently low serum C3 levels, often related to the presence of C3 nephritic factors that continuously activate the alternative complement pathway, leading to complement consumption.

 

Option C: Lupus Nephritis: In systemic lupus erythematosus (SLE), including lupus nephritis, both classical and alternative complement pathways can be activated by immune complexes, leading to persistent depression of complement components, including C3.

 

Option D: Glomerulonephritis Related to Bacterial Endocarditis: This condition is also associated with immune complex deposition that can consume complement. Persistent low serum C3 levels may be observed, depending on the chronicity and activity of the infection.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Serum complement levels, specifically C3, can be a valuable clinical marker in the diagnosis and monitoring of glomerular diseases. Poststreptococcal glomerulonephritis typically presents with transient low serum C3 levels, which recover within a few weeks, unlike other conditions such as membranoproliferative glomerulonephritis, lupus nephritis, and glomerulonephritis related to bacterial endocarditis, which may show persistent low levels indicative of ongoing complement activation and consumption.

 

C3 Levels in Different Types of GN:

 

 

(Ref: Robbins 10th 906)

questions.text: A 40-year-old man presents with a 3-month history of recurrent sinusitis, cough, and hemoptysis. Physical examination reveals saddle-nose deformity and purpuric skin lesions on the lower extremities. Laboratory studies show elevated inflammatory markers and positive anti-neutrophil cytoplasmic antibodies (c-ANCA). In Wegener’s granulomatosis, kidney has which of the following lesions?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Crescentic glomerulonephritis

 

Option C:

 

Wegener's granulomatosis often presents with necrotizing granulomatous inflammation in the respiratory tract and necrotizing vasculitis affecting small- to medium-sized vessels. In the kidney, this vasculitis can lead to crescentic glomerulonephritis, which is a characteristic renal manifestation.

 

Explanation:

 

Options A: and Option C: glomerular and interstitial granuloma is not a typical finding in Wegener's granulomatosis.

 

Wegener's granulomatosis primarily involves small vessels and may cause granulomatous inflammation in the interstitial tissues, but glomerular and interstitial granulomas are not a defining feature.

 

Option D: Glomerulosclerosis is not a typical lesion seen in Wegener's granulomatosis. The primary renal involvement is characterized by crescentic glomerulonephritis.

 

Educational Objective:

 

In Wegener’s granulomatosis kidney shows crescentic glomerulonephritis.

 

(Ref: Robbins 10th/909)

questions.text: The electron microscopy is virtually diagnostic in renal biopsy study of:
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Alport syndrome

 

Option C:

 

Alport syndrome shows a characteristic electron microscopy finding of the glomerular basement membrane (GBM), which is described as basket-weaving, due to splitting and lamellation of the lamina densa. This is a pathognomonic feature.

 

 

Explanation:

 

Option A: Goodpasture syndrome is characterized by the presence of anti-GBM antibodies leading to glomerulonephritis and pulmonary hemorrhage. Electron microscopy may show non-specific findings of glomerular damage rather than the specific changes seen in Alport syndrome.

 

Option B: Churg-Strauss syndrome, also known as eosinophilic granulomatosis with polyangiitis, is a form of vasculitis. Renal involvement can occur, but electron microscopy findings are not diagnostic of the condition.

 

Option D: Wegener’s granulomatosis, now known as granulomatosis with polyangiitis, may show evidence of small vessel vasculitis on biopsy, but electron microscopy is not typically diagnostic for this condition.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Alport syndrome's definitive morphological lesions are observable only by electron microscopy, which reveals a distinctive appearance of the GBM.

 

(Ref: Robbins 10th/ 922)

questions.text: A 35-year-old man with a history of intravenous drug abuse presents with worsening kidney function. Renal biopsy reveals collapsing variant of focal segmental glomerulosclerosis (FSGS). Which of the following features is characteristic of this variant and is associated with a worse prognosis?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Collapsing

 

Option B:

 

The collapsing variant is characterized by the collapse of glomerular capillaries and overt tuft collapse, which leads to rapid progression of renal disease and a poorer prognosis, making this the correct answer.

 

Five mutually exclusive variants of focal seg­mental glomerulosclerosis (FSGS) may be dis­tinguished by the pathological findings seen on renal biopsy

 

  • Collapsing variant

  • Glomerular tip lesion variant

  • Cellular variant

  • Perihilar variant

  • Not otherwise specified variant (NOS)

 

Explanation:

 

Option A: The tip variant of FSGS affects the segment of the glomerulus near the proximal tubule and is associated with better outcomes compared to other variants.

 

Option C: NOS (not otherwise specified) variant is the most common type of FSGS and has a variable prognosis that is generally not as poor as the collapsing variant.

 

Option D: The perihilar variant of FSGS has sclerotic lesions predominantly at the vascular pole of the glomerulus and does not typically progress as rapidly as the collapsing variant.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The NOS variant is the most common subtype and collapsing FSGS has worst prognosis.

 

(Ref: Robbin’s 10th/ 916)

choices.text: Fusion of foot processes of the glomerular epithelial cells
Deposition of electron dense material in the basement membrane

questions.text: A 7 year old boy presented with generalized edema. Urine examination revealed marked albuminuria. Serum biochemical examinations showed hypoalbuminemia with hyperlipidemia. Kidney biopsy was undertaken. On light microscopic examination, the kidney appeared normal. Electron microscopic examination is most likely to reveal:
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Fusion of foot process of the glomerular epi­thelial cells

 

Option A:

 

Fusion of foot processes of the glomerular epithelial cells is characteristic of minimal change disease. Electron microscopy will reveal effacement or fusion of the podocyte foot processes without immune complex deposition or complement activation.

 

The child is presenting with features likely of Nephrotic syndrome whose most frequent cause in children is minimal change disease or lipoid nephrosis.

 

  • Light microscopy there is no abnormality whereas on electron microscopy there is fusion of foot pro­cesses of the glomerular epithelial cells with normal glomeruli.

 

Explanation:

 

Option B: Rarefaction of the glomerular basement membrane is not a feature of MCD but may be seen in other kidney diseases, such as Alport syndrome.

 

Option C: Deposition of electron-dense material in the basement membrane is typically observed in diseases such as membranous nephropathy, not MCD.

 

Option D: A thin basement membrane is characteristic of thin basement membrane disease, a condition separate from MCD.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The primary finding in minimal change disease on electron microscopy is the effacement or fusion of podocyte foot processes, which helps in distinguishing it from other glomerular diseases that may present with normal findings on light microscopy but show specific abnormalities on electron microscopy.

 

(Ref: Robbins 10th/ 914)

questions.text: The prognosis of rapidly proliferating glomerulonephritis depends upon which of the following?
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Number of crescents

 

Option A:

 

The Number of Crescents: This is the most important prognostic factor in rapidly proliferating glomerulonephritis. The more glomeruli that contain crescents, especially when more than 50% of the glomeruli are involved, the worse the prognosis is likely to be due to the associated reduction in functional renal tissue.

 

Crescents are formed by the proliferation of cells in Bowman's space (glomerular parietal epithelial cells, infiltrating monocytes/macrophages, and other cells). The presence of crescents indicates severe glomerular injury and inflammation, and the degree of crescent formation correlates with the extent of damage. The more crescents present, the greater the loss of functional glomerular tissue, leading to impaired kidney function and poorer prognosis.

 

Explanation:

 

Option B: Size of Crescents: While the size of crescents might reflect the severity of the initial injury, it is not as directly correlated with the prognosis as the number of affected glomeruli.

 

Option C: Shape of Crescents: The shape does not typically provide prognostic information. Crescents, by definition, are semi-lunar and their presence, regardless of shape, suggests significant pathology.

 

Option D: Cellularity of Crescents: Cellularity can give clues about the activity of the disease process (more cellular crescents may indicate more active disease), but again, the number of crescents is a stronger prognostic indicator.

 

Educational Objective:

 

In rapidly proliferating glomerulonephritis, the prognosis is primarily dependent on the number of crescents within the glomeruli, as this reflects the degree of glomerular damage and potential loss of kidney function.

 

(Ref: Robbins 10th/ 909)

questions.text: Tram track appearance on histopathology of kidney is seen in:
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Membranoproliferative glomerulonephritis

 

Option B:

 

Membranoproliferative glomerulonephritis involves both mesangial and subendothelial immune complex deposits. It typically presents with a lobular appearance on histopathology and a “tram track appearance”.

 

Explanation:

 

Option A: Membranous nephropathy is characterized by the presence of subepithelial immune complex deposits, leading to a characteristic spike and dome appearance on histopathology.

 

Option C: IgA nephropathy is characterized by the deposition of IgA immune complexes in the mesangium of the glomeruli. It usually does not present with tram track appearance.

 

Option D: Crescentic glomerulonephritis is associated with the formation of crescents in Bowman's space due to severe inflammation and glomerular injury. It does not typically present with tram track appearance.

 

 

(Ref: Robbins 10th/ 917)

choices.text: Tubular cell + mesangial cell + fibrin

questions.text: Crescents are derived from which of the following?
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Epithelial cells + fibrin + macrophage

 

Option A:

 

Epithelial cells + fibrin + macrophage Crescents are formed within Bowman's space during severe glomerular injury. Parietal epithelial cells line Bowman's capsule, and they proliferate in response to injury. Macrophages infiltrate the space as part of the inflammatory response, and fibrin is deposited due to the leakage of plasma proteins through the injured glomerular capillaries. This option correctly identifies the components of a crescent in proliferative forms of glomerulonephritis.

 

Explanation:

 

The composition of crescents in glomerulonephritis:

 

Option B: Mesangial cell + fibrin + macrophage.  While mesangial cells are indeed a component of the glomerulus and can proliferate in response to injury, they are not typically a part of the cellular makeup of crescents. Crescents are primarily composed of parietal epithelial cells, not mesangial cells.

 

Option C: Tubular cell + mesangial cell + fibrin Tubular cells are part of the nephron but not of the glomerulus, and they do not contribute to crescent formation. Mesangial cells, as mentioned earlier, reside within the glomerulus but do not form crescents.

 

Option D: Neutrophil + tubular cell + fibrin Neutrophils may be present in the glomerulus as part of an inflammatory response but are not a defining component of crescents. Tubular cells are not involved in crescent formation.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Crescents are formed by proliferation of parietal cells and by migration of monocytes and macrophages into the urinary space. Neutrophils and lymphocytes may be present. Fibrin strands are frequently promi­nent between the cellular layers in the crescents. The escape of fibrinogen into Bowman space and its conver­sion to fibrin are an important contributor to crescent formation.

 

(Ref: Robbins 10th/ 911)

questions.text: Flea bitten appearance of the kidney is seen in:
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Malignant hypertension

 

Option A:

 

 

Explanation:

 

Option B: Benign hypertension, also known as essential hypertension, is associated with long-standing high blood pressure. It can lead to hypertensive nephrosclerosis, characterized by arteriolar hyalinosis and ischemic changes in the kidney. However, "flea-bitten" appearance is not a specific term associated with this condition.

 

Option C: Chronic pyelonephritis is a condition characterized by chronic inflammation of the renal parenchyma, often secondary to recurrent urinary tract infections. It typically presents with scarring and atrophy of the renal papillae.

 

Option D: Long standing and uncontrolled diabetes can lead to diabetic nephropathy. This condition is characterized by glomerular basement membrane thickening and nodular glomerulosclerosis (Kimmelstiel-Wilson nodules).

 

Educational Objective:

 

Mnemonic for differential diagnosis of flea bitten kid­ney: We HaTe PSM

 

  • We -Wegener’s granulomatosis

  • HaTe – Henoch Schonlein purpura; HUS;TTP

  • P- Poststreptococcal glomerulonephritis (PSGN); Polyarteritis nodosa (PAN)

  • S-Subacute bacterial endocarditis (SABE)

  • M- Malignant hypertension.

 

(Ref: Robbins 10th/ 939)
